2.verse: Before anything else existed, there was Christ,* with God. He has always been alive and is himself God.

3.verse: He created everything there is—nothing exists that he didn’t make.

4.verse: Eternal life is in him, and this life gives light to all mankind.

5.verse: His life is the light that shines through the darkness—and the darkness can never extinguish it.

6.verse: God sent John the Baptist as a witness to the fact that Jesus Christ is the true Light.

7.verse: God sent John the Baptist as a witness to the fact that Jesus Christ is the true Light.

8.verse: John himself was not the Light; he was only a witness to identify it.

9.verse: Later on, the one who is the true Light arrived to shine on everyone coming into the world.

10.verse: But although he made the world, the world didn’t recognize him when he came.

11.verse: Even in his own land and among his own people, the Jews, he was not accepted. Only a few would welcome and receive him. But to all who received him, he gave the right to become children of God. All they needed to do was to trust him to save them.

12.verse: Even in his own land and among his own people, the Jews, he was not accepted. Only a few would welcome and receive him. But to all who received him, he gave the right to become children of God. All they needed to do was to trust him to save them.

13.verse: All those who believe this are reborn!—not a physical rebirth resulting from human passion or plan—but from the will of God.

14.verse: And Christ became a human being and lived here on earth among us and was full of loving forgiveness* and truth. And some of us have seen his glory*—the glory of the only Son of the heavenly Father!*

15.verse: John pointed him out to the people, telling the crowds, “This is the one I was talking about when I said, ‘Someone is coming who is greater by far than I am—for he existed long before I did!’”

16.verse: We have all benefited from the rich blessings he brought to us—blessing upon blessing heaped upon us!

17.verse: For Moses gave us only the Law with its rigid demands and merciless justice, while Jesus Christ brought us loving forgiveness as well.

18.verse: No one has ever actually seen God, but, of course, his only Son has, for he is the companion of the Father and has told us all about him.

19.verse: The Jewish leaders sent priests and assistant priests from Jerusalem to ask John whether he claimed to be the Messiah.

20.verse: He denied it flatly. “I am not the Christ,” he said.

21.verse: “Well then, who are you?” they asked. “Are you Elijah?” “No,” he replied. “Are you the Prophet?” “No.”

22.verse: “Then who are you? Tell us, so we can give an answer to those who sent us. What do you have to say for yourself?”

23.verse: He replied, “I am a voice from the barren wilderness, shouting as Isaiah prophesied, ‘Get ready for the coming of the Lord!’”

24.verse: Then those who were sent by the Pharisees asked him, “If you aren’t the Messiah or Elijah or the Prophet, what right do you have to baptize?”

25.verse: Then those who were sent by the Pharisees asked him, “If you aren’t the Messiah or Elijah or the Prophet, what right do you have to baptize?”

26.verse: John told them, “I merely baptize with water, but right here in the crowd is someone you have never met,

27.verse: who will soon begin his ministry among you, and I am not even fit to be his slave.”

28.verse: This incident took place at Bethany, a village on the other side of the Jordan River where John was baptizing.

29.verse: The next day John saw Jesus coming toward him and said, “Look! There is the Lamb of God who takes away the world’s sin!

30.verse: He is the one I was talking about when I said, ‘Soon a man far greater than I am is coming, who existed long before me!’

31.verse: I didn’t know he was the one, but I am here baptizing with water in order to point him out to the nation of Israel.”

32.verse: Then John told about seeing the Holy Spirit in the form of a dove descending from heaven and resting upon Jesus.

33.verse: “I didn’t know he was the one,” John said again, “but at the time God sent me to baptize he told me, ‘When you see the Holy Spirit descending and resting upon someone—he is the one you are looking for. He is the one who baptizes with the Holy Spirit.’

34.verse: I saw it happen to this man, and I therefore testify that he is the Son of God.”

35.verse: The following day as John was standing with two of his disciples,

36.verse: Jesus walked by. John looked at him intently and then declared, “See! There is the Lamb of God!”

37.verse: Then John’s two disciples turned and followed Jesus.

38.verse: Jesus looked around and saw them following. “What do you want?” he asked them. “Sir,” they replied, “where do you live?”

39.verse: “Come and see,” he said. So they went with him to the place where he was staying and were with him from about four o’clock that afternoon until the evening.

40.verse: (One of these men was Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother.)

41.verse: Andrew then went to find his brother Peter and told him, “We have found the Messiah!”

42.verse: And he brought Peter to meet Jesus. Jesus looked intently at Peter for a moment and then said, “You are Simon, John’s son—but you shall be called Peter, the rock!”

43.verse: The next day Jesus decided to go to Galilee. He found Philip and told him, “Come with me.”

44.verse: (Philip was from Bethsaida, Andrew and Peter’s hometown.)

45.verse: Philip now went off to look for Nathanael and told him, “We have found the Messiah!—the very person Moses and the prophets told about! His name is Jesus, the son of Joseph from Nazareth!”

46.verse: “Nazareth!” exclaimed Nathanael. “Can anything good come from there?” “Just come and see for yourself,” Philip declared.

47.verse: As they approached, Jesus said, “Here comes an honest man—a true son of Israel.”

48.verse: “How do you know what I am like?” Nathanael demanded. And Jesus replied, “I could see you under the fig tree before Philip found you.”

49.verse: Nathanael replied, “Sir, you are the Son of God—the King of Israel!”

50.verse: Jesus asked him, “Do you believe all this just because I told you I had seen you under the fig tree? You will see greater proofs than this.

51.verse: You will even see heaven open and the angels of God coming back and forth to me, the Messiah.”

1.verse: Two days later Jesus’ mother was a guest at a wedding in the village of Cana in Galilee,

2.verse: and Jesus and his disciples were invited too.

3.verse: The wine supply ran out during the festivities, and Jesus’ mother came to him with the problem.

4.verse: “I can’t help you now,” he said. “It isn’t yet my time for miracles.”

5.verse: But his mother told the servants, “Do whatever he tells you to.”

6.verse: Six stone waterpots were standing there; they were used for Jewish ceremonial purposes and held perhaps twenty to thirty gallons each.

7.verse: Then Jesus told the servants to fill them to the brim with water. When this was done he said, “Dip some out and take it to the master of ceremonies.”

8.verse: Then Jesus told the servants to fill them to the brim with water. When this was done he said, “Dip some out and take it to the master of ceremonies.”

9.verse: When the master of ceremonies tasted the water that was now wine, not knowing where it had come from (though, of course, the servants did), he called the bridegroom over.

10.verse: “This is wonderful stuff!” he said. “You’re different from most. Usually a host uses the best wine first, and afterwards, when everyone is full and doesn’t care, then he brings out the less expensive brands. But you have kept the best for the last!”

11.verse: This miracle at Cana in Galilee was Jesus’ first public demonstration of his heaven-sent power. And his disciples believed that he really was the Messiah.

12.verse: After the wedding he left for Capernaum for a few days with his mother, brothers, and disciples.

13.verse: Then it was time for the annual Jewish Passover celebration, and Jesus went to Jerusalem.

14.verse: In the Temple area he saw merchants selling cattle, sheep, and doves for sacrifices, and moneychangers behind their counters.

15.verse: Jesus made a whip from some ropes and chased them all out, and drove out the sheep and oxen, scattering the moneychangers’ coins over the floor and turning over their tables!

16.verse: Then, going over to the men selling doves, he told them, “Get these things out of here. Don’t turn my Father’s House into a market!”

17.verse: Then his disciples remembered this prophecy from the Scriptures: “Concern for God’s House will be my undoing.”

18.verse: “What right have you to order them out?” the Jewish leaders demanded. “If you have this authority from God, show us a miracle to prove it.”

19.verse: “All right,” Jesus replied, “this is the miracle I will do for you: Destroy this sanctuary and in three days I will raise it up!”

20.verse: “What!” they exclaimed. “It took forty-six years to build this Temple, and you can do it in three days?”

21.verse: But by “this sanctuary” he meant his body.

22.verse: After he came back to life again, the disciples remembered his saying this and realized that what he had quoted from the Scriptures really did refer to him, and had all come true!

23.verse: Because of the miracles he did in Jerusalem at the Passover celebration, many people were convinced that he was indeed the Messiah.

24.verse: But Jesus didn’t trust them, for he knew mankind to the core. No one needed to tell him how changeable human nature is!

1.verse: After dark one night a Jewish religious leader named Nicodemus, a member of the sect of the Pharisees, came for an interview with Jesus. “Sir,” he said, “we all know that God has sent you to teach us. Your miracles are proof enough of this.”

2.verse: After dark one night a Jewish religious leader named Nicodemus, a member of the sect of the Pharisees, came for an interview with Jesus. “Sir,” he said, “we all know that God has sent you to teach us. Your miracles are proof enough of this.”

3.verse: Jesus replied, “With all the earnestness I possess I tell you this: Unless you are born again, you can never get into the Kingdom of God.”

4.verse: “Born again!” exclaimed Nicodemus. “What do you mean? How can an old man go back into his mother’s womb and be born again?”

5.verse: Jesus replied, “What I am telling you so earnestly is this: Unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the Kingdom of God.

6.verse: Men can only reproduce human life, but the Holy Spirit gives new life from heaven;

7.verse: so don’t be surprised at my statement that you must be born again!

8.verse: Just as you can hear the wind but can’t tell where it comes from or where it will go next, so it is with the Spirit. We do not know on whom he will next bestow this life from heaven.”

9.verse: “What do you mean?” Nicodemus asked.

10.verse: Jesus replied, “You, a respected Jewish teacher, and yet you don’t understand these things? I am telling you what I know and have seen—and yet you won’t believe me.

11.verse: Jesus replied, “You, a respected Jewish teacher, and yet you don’t understand these things? I am telling you what I know and have seen—and yet you won’t believe me.

12.verse: But if you don’t even believe me when I tell you about such things as these that happen here among men, how can you possibly believe if I tell you what is going on in heaven?

13.verse: For only I, the Messiah, have come to earth and will return to heaven again.

14.verse: And as Moses in the wilderness lifted up the bronze image of a serpent on a pole, even so I must be lifted up upon a pole,

15.verse: so that anyone who believes in me will have eternal life.

16.verse: For God loved the world so much that he gave his only Son so that anyone who believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.

17.verse: God did not send his Son into the world to condemn it, but to save it.

18.verse: “There is no eternal doom awaiting those who trust him to save them. But those who don’t trust him have already been tried and condemned for not believing in the only Son of God.

19.verse: Their sentence is based on this fact: that the Light from heaven came into the world, but they loved the darkness more than the Light, for their deeds were evil.

20.verse: They hated the heavenly Light because they wanted to sin in the darkness. They stayed away from that Light for fear their sins would be exposed and they would be punished.

21.verse: But those doing right come gladly to the Light to let everyone see that they are doing what God wants them to.”

22.verse: Afterwards Jesus and his disciples left Jerusalem and stayed for a while in Judea and baptized there.

23.verse: At this time John the Baptist was not yet in prison. He was baptizing at Aenon, near Salim, because there was plenty of water there.

24.verse: At this time John the Baptist was not yet in prison. He was baptizing at Aenon, near Salim, because there was plenty of water there.

25.verse: One day someone began an argument with John’s disciples, telling them that Jesus’ baptism was best.

26.verse: So they came to John and said, “Master, the man you met on the other side of the Jordan River—the one you said was the Messiah—he is baptizing too, and everybody is going over there instead of coming here to us.”

27.verse: John replied, “God in heaven appoints each man’s work.

28.verse: My work is to prepare the way for that man so that everyone will go to him. You yourselves know how plainly I told you that I am not the Messiah. I am here to prepare the way for him—that is all.

29.verse: The crowds will naturally go to the main attraction—the bride will go where the bridegroom is! A bridegroom’s friends rejoice with him. I am the Bridegroom’s friend, and I am filled with joy at his success.

30.verse: He must become greater and greater, and I must become less and less.

31.verse: “He has come from heaven and is greater than anyone else. I am of the earth, and my understanding is limited to the things of earth.

32.verse: He tells what he has seen and heard, but how few believe what he tells them!

33.verse: Those who believe him discover that God is a fountain of truth. For this one—sent by God—speaks God’s words, for God’s Spirit is upon him without measure or limit.

34.verse: Those who believe him discover that God is a fountain of truth. For this one—sent by God—speaks God’s words, for God’s Spirit is upon him without measure or limit.

35.verse: The Father loves this man because he is his Son, and God has given him everything there is.

36.verse: And all who trust him—God’s Son—to save them have eternal life; those who don’t believe and obey him shall never see heaven, but the wrath of God remains upon them.”

7.verse: Soon a Samaritan woman came to draw water, and Jesus asked her for a drink.

8.verse: He was alone at the time as his disciples had gone into the village to buy some food.

9.verse: The woman was surprised that a Jew would ask a “despised Samaritan” for anything—usually they wouldn’t even speak to them!—and she remarked about this to Jesus.

10.verse: He replied, “If you only knew what a wonderful gift God has for you, and who I am, you would ask me for some living water!”

11.verse: “But you don’t have a rope or a bucket,” she said, “and this is a very deep well! Where would you get this living water?

12.verse: And besides, are you greater than our ancestor Jacob? How can you offer better water than this which he and his sons and cattle enjoyed?”

13.verse: Jesus replied that people soon became thirsty again after drinking this water.

14.verse: “But the water I give them,” he said, “becomes a perpetual spring within them, watering them forever with eternal life.”

15.verse: “Please, sir,” the woman said, “give me some of that water! Then I’ll never be thirsty again and won’t have to make this long trip out here every day.”

16.verse: “Go and get your husband,” Jesus told her.

17.verse: “But I’m not married,” the woman replied. “All too true!” Jesus said. “For you have had five husbands, and you aren’t even married to the man you’re living with now.”

18.verse: “But I’m not married,” the woman replied. “All too true!” Jesus said. “For you have had five husbands, and you aren’t even married to the man you’re living with now.”

19.verse: “Sir,” the woman said, “you must be a prophet.

20.verse: But say, tell me, why is it that you Jews insist that Jerusalem is the only place of worship, while we Samaritans claim it is here at Mount Gerizim, where our ancestors worshiped?”

21.verse: Jesus replied, “The time is coming, ma’am, when we will no longer be concerned about whether to worship the Father here or in Jerusalem. 26.verse: Then Jesus told her, “I am the Messiah!”

27.verse: Just then his disciples arrived. They were surprised to find him talking to a woman, but none of them asked him why, or what they had been discussing.

28.verse: Then the woman left her waterpot beside the well and went back to the village and told everyone, “Come and meet a man who told me everything I ever did! Can this be the Messiah?”

31.verse: Meanwhile, the disciples were urging Jesus to eat.

32.verse: “No,” he said, “I have some food you don’t know about.”

33.verse: “Who brought it to him?” the disciples asked each other.

34.verse: Then Jesus explained: “My nourishment comes from doing the will of God who sent me, and from finishing his work.

35.verse: Do you think the work of harvesting will not begin until the summer ends four months from now? Look around you! Vast fields of human souls are ripening all around us, and are ready now for reaping.

36.verse: The reapers will be paid good wages and will be gathering eternal souls into the granaries of heaven! What joys await the sower and the reaper, both together!

37.verse: For it is true that one sows and someone else reaps.

38.verse: I sent you to reap where you didn’t sow; others did the work, and you received the harvest.”

39.verse: Many from the Samaritan village believed he was the Messiah because of the woman’s report: “He told me everything I ever did!”

40.verse: When they came out to see him at the well, they begged him to stay at their village; and he did, for two days, long enough for many of them to believe in him after hearing him.

42.verse: Then they said to the woman, “Now we believe because we have heard him ourselves, not just because of what you told us. He is indeed the Savior of the world.”

48.verse: Jesus asked, “Won’t any of you believe in me unless I do more and more miracles?”

49.verse: The official pled, “Sir, please come now before my child dies.”

50.verse: Then Jesus told him, “Go back home. Your son is healed!” And the man believed Jesus and started home.

51.verse: While he was on his way, some of his servants met him with the news that all was well—his son had recovered.

52.verse: He asked them when the lad had begun to feel better, and they replied, “Yesterday afternoon at about one o’clock his fever suddenly disappeared!”

53.verse: Then the father realized it was the same moment that Jesus had told him, “Your son is healed.” And the officer and his entire household believed that Jesus was the Messiah.

54.verse: This was Jesus’ second miracle in Galilee after coming from Judea.

1.verse: Afterwards Jesus returned to Jerusalem for one of the Jewish religious holidays.

2.verse: Inside the city, near the Sheep Gate, was Bethesda Pool, with five covered platforms or porches surrounding it.

3.verse: Crowds of sick folks—lame, blind, or with paralyzed limbs—lay on the platforms (waiting for a certain movement of the water,

4.verse: for an angel of the Lord came from time to time and disturbed the water, and the first person to step down into it afterwards was healed).

5.verse: One of the men lying there had been sick for thirty-eight years.

6.verse: When Jesus saw him and knew how long he had been ill, he asked him, “Would you like to get well?”

7.verse: “I can’t,” the sick man said, “for I have no one to help me into the pool at the movement of the water. While I am trying to get there, someone else always gets in ahead of me.”

8.verse: Jesus told him, “Stand up, roll up your sleeping mat and go on home!”

9.verse: Instantly, the man was healed! He rolled up the mat and began walking! But it was on the Sabbath when this miracle was done.

10.verse: So the Jewish leaders objected. They said to the man who was cured, “You can’t work on the Sabbath! It’s illegal to carry that sleeping mat!”

11.verse: “The man who healed me told me to,” was his reply.

12.verse: “Who said such a thing as that?” they demanded.

13.verse: The man didn’t know, and Jesus had disappeared into the crowd.

14.verse: But afterwards Jesus found him in the Temple and told him, “Now you are well; don’t sin as you did before, or something even worse may happen to you.”

15.verse: Then the man went to find the Jewish leaders and told them it was Jesus who had healed him.

16.verse: So they began harassing Jesus as a Sabbath breaker.

17.verse: But Jesus replied, “My Father constantly does good, and I’m following his example.”

18.verse: Then the Jewish leaders were all the more eager to kill him because in addition to disobeying their Sabbath laws, he had spoken of God as his Father, thereby making himself equal with God.

19.verse: Jesus replied, “The Son can do nothing by himself. He does only what he sees the Father doing, and in the same way.

20.verse: For the Father loves the Son, and tells him everything he is doing; and the Son will do far more awesome miracles than this man’s healing.

21.verse: He will even raise from the dead anyone he wants to, just as the Father does.

22.verse: And the Father leaves all judgment of sin to his Son,

23.verse: so that everyone will honor the Son, just as they honor the Father. But if you refuse to honor God’s Son, whom he sent to you, then you are certainly not honoring the Father.

24.verse: “I say emphatically that anyone who listens to my message and believes in God who sent me has eternal life, and will never be damned for his sins, but has already passed out of death into life.

25.verse: “And I solemnly declare that the time is coming, in fact, it is here, when the dead shall hear my voice—the voice of the Son of God—and those who listen shall live.

26.verse: The Father has life in himself, and has granted his Son to have life in himself,

27.verse: and to judge the sins of all mankind because he is the Son of Man.

28.verse: Don’t be so surprised! Indeed the time is coming when all the dead in their graves shall hear the voice of God’s Son,

29.verse: and shall rise again—those who have done good, to eternal life; and those who have continued in evil, to judgment.

30.verse: “But I pass no judgment without consulting the Father. I judge as I am told. And my judgment is absolutely fair and just, for it is according to the will of God who sent me and is not merely my own.

31.verse: “When I make claims about myself they aren’t believed,

32.verse: but someone else, yes, John the Baptist, is making these claims for me too. You have gone out to listen to his preaching, and I can assure you that all he says about me is true!

33.verse: but someone else, yes, John the Baptist, is making these claims for me too. You have gone out to listen to his preaching, and I can assure you that all he says about me is true!

34.verse: But the truest witness I have is not from a man, though I have reminded you about John’s witness so that you will believe in me and be saved.

35.verse: John shone brightly for a while, and you benefited and rejoiced,

36.verse: but I have a greater witness than John. I refer to the miracles I do; these have been assigned me by the Father, and they prove that the Father has sent me.

37.verse: And the Father himself has also testified about me, though not appearing to you personally, or speaking to you directly.

38.verse: But you are not listening to him, for you refuse to believe me—the one sent to you with God’s message.

39.verse: “You search the Scriptures, for you believe they give you eternal life. And the Scriptures point to me!

40.verse: Yet you won’t come to me so that I can give you this life eternal!

41.verse: “Your approval or disapproval means nothing to me, for as I know so well, you don’t have God’s love within you.

42.verse: “Your approval or disapproval means nothing to me, for as I know so well, you don’t have God’s love within you.

43.verse: I know, because I have come to you representing my Father and you refuse to welcome me, though you readily enough receive those who aren’t sent from him, but represent only themselves!

44.verse: No wonder you can’t believe! For you gladly honor each other, but you don’t care about the honor that comes from the only God!

45.verse: “Yet it is not I who will accuse you of this to the Father—Moses will! Moses, on whose laws you set your hopes of heaven.

46.verse: For you have refused to believe Moses. He wrote about me, but you refuse to believe him, so you refuse to believe in me.

47.verse: And since you don’t believe what he wrote, no wonder you don’t believe me either.”

1.verse: After this, Jesus went to Galilee, going from village to village, for he wanted to stay out of Judea where the Jewish leaders were plotting his death.

2.verse: But soon it was time for the Tabernacle Ceremonies, one of the annual Jewish holidays,

3.verse: and Jesus’ brothers urged him to go to Judea for the celebration. “Go where more people can see your miracles!” they scoffed.

4.verse: “You can’t be famous when you hide like this! If you’re so great, prove it to the world!”

5.verse: For even his brothers didn’t believe in him.

6.verse: Jesus replied, “It is not the right time for me to go now. But you can go anytime and it will make no difference,

7.verse: for the world can’t hate you; but it does hate me, because I accuse it of sin and evil.

8.verse: You go on, and I’ll come later when it is the right time.”

9.verse: So he remained in Galilee.

10.verse: But after his brothers had left for the celebration, then he went too, though secretly, staying out of the public eye.

11.verse: The Jewish leaders tried to find him at the celebration and kept asking if anyone had seen him.

12.verse: There was a lot of discussion about him among the crowds. Some said, “He’s a wonderful man,” while others said, “No, he’s duping the public.”

13.verse: But no one had the courage to speak out for him in public for fear of reprisals from the Jewish leaders.

14.verse: Then, midway through the festival, Jesus went up to the Temple and preached openly.

15.verse: The Jewish leaders were surprised when they heard him. “How can he know so much when he’s never been to our schools?” they asked.

16.verse: So Jesus told them, “I’m not teaching you my own thoughts, but those of God who sent me.

17.verse: If any of you really determines to do God’s will, then you will certainly know whether my teaching is from God or is merely my own.

18.verse: Anyone presenting his own ideas is looking for praise for himself, but anyone seeking to honor the one who sent him is a good and true person.

28.verse: So Jesus, in a sermon in the Temple, called out, “Yes, you know me and where I was born and raised, but I am the representative of one you don’t know, and he is Truth.

29.verse: I know him because I was with him, and he sent me to you.”

30.verse: Then the Jewish leaders sought to arrest him; but no hand was laid on him, for God’s time had not yet come.

31.verse: Many among the crowds at the Temple believed on him. “After all,” they said, “what miracles do you expect the Messiah to do that this man hasn’t done?”

32.verse: When the Pharisees heard that the crowds were in this mood, they and the chief priests sent officers to arrest Jesus.

33.verse: But Jesus told them, “Not yet! I am to be here a little longer. Then I shall return to the one who sent me.

34.verse: You will search for me but not find me. And you won’t be able to come where I am!”

35.verse: The Jewish leaders were puzzled by this statement. “Where is he planning to go?” they asked. “Maybe he is thinking of leaving the country and going as a missionary among the Jews in other lands, or maybe even to the Gentiles!

36.verse: What does he mean about our looking for him and not being able to find him, and, ‘You won’t be able to come where I am’?”

37.verse: On the last day, the climax of the holidays, Jesus shouted to the crowds, “If anyone is thirsty, let him come to me and drink.

38.verse: For the Scriptures declare that rivers of living water shall flow from the inmost being of anyone who believes in me.”

39.verse: (He was speaking of the Holy Spirit, who would be given to everyone believing in him; but the Spirit had not yet been given, because Jesus had not yet returned to his glory in heaven.)

40.verse: When the crowds heard him say this, some of them declared, “This man surely is the prophet who will come just before the Messiah.”

41.verse: Others said, “He is the Messiah.” Still others, “But he can’t be! Will the Messiah come from Galilee? For the Scriptures clearly state that the Messiah will be born of the royal line of David, in Bethlehem, the village where David was born.”

45.verse: The Temple police who had been sent to arrest him returned to the chief priests and Pharisees. “Why didn’t you bring him in?” they demanded.

46.verse: “He says such wonderful things!” they mumbled. “We’ve never heard anything like it.”

47.verse: “So you also have been led astray?” the Pharisees mocked.

48.verse: “Is there a single one of us Jewish rulers or Pharisees who believes he is the Messiah?

49.verse: These stupid crowds do, yes; but what do they know about it? A curse upon them anyway!”

50.verse: Then Nicodemus spoke up. (Remember him? He was the Jewish leader who came secretly to interview Jesus.)

51.verse: “Is it legal to convict a man before he is even tried?” he asked.

52.verse: They replied, “Are you a wretched Galilean too? Search the Scriptures and see for yourself—no prophets will come from Galilee!”

53.verse: Then the meeting broke up and everybody went home.

2.verse: but early the next morning he was back again at the Temple. A crowd soon gathered, and he sat down and talked to them.

3.verse: As he was speaking, the Jewish leaders and Pharisees brought a woman caught in adultery and placed her out in front of the staring crowd.

4.verse: “Teacher,” they said to Jesus, “this woman was caught in the very act of adultery.

5.verse: Moses’ law says to kill her. What about it?”

6.verse: They were trying to trap him into saying something they could use against him, but Jesus stooped down and wrote in the dust with his finger.

7.verse: They kept demanding an answer, so he stood up again and said, “All right, hurl the stones at her until she dies. But only he who never sinned may throw the first!”

8.verse: Then he stooped down again and wrote some more in the dust.

9.verse: And the Jewish leaders slipped away one by one, beginning with the eldest, until only Jesus was left in front of the crowd with the woman.

10.verse: Then Jesus stood up again and said to her, “Where are your accusers? Didn’t even one of them condemn you?”

11.verse: “No, sir,” she said. And Jesus said, “Neither do I. Go and sin no more.”

12.verse: Later, in one of his talks, Jesus said to the people, “I am the Light of the world. So if you follow me, you won’t be stumbling through the darkness, for living light will flood your path.”

13.verse: The Pharisees replied, “You are boasting—and lying!”

14.verse: Jesus told them, “These claims are true even though I make them concerning myself. For I know where I came from and where I am going, but you don’t know this about me.

15.verse: You pass judgment on me without knowing the facts. I am not judging you now;

16.verse: but if I were, it would be an absolutely correct judgment in every respect, for I have with me the Father who sent me.

17.verse: Your laws say that if two men agree on something that has happened, their witness is accepted as fact.

18.verse: Well, I am one witness, and my Father who sent me is the other.”

19.verse: “Where is your father?” they asked. Jesus answered, “You don’t know who I am, so you don’t know who my Father is. If you knew me, then you would know him too.”

20.verse: Jesus made these statements while in the section of the Temple known as the Treasury. But he was not arrested, for his time had not yet run out.

21.verse: Later he said to them again, “I am going away; and you will search for me, and die in your sins. And you cannot come where I am going.”

22.verse: The Jews asked, “Is he planning suicide? What does he mean, ‘You cannot come where I am going’?”

23.verse: Then he said to them, “You are from below; I am from above. You are of this world; I am not.

24.verse: That is why I said that you will die in your sins; for unless you believe that I am the Messiah, the Son of God, you will die in your sins.”

25.verse: “Tell us who you are,” they demanded. He replied, “I am the one I have always claimed to be.

26.verse: I could condemn you for much and teach you much, but I won’t, for I say only what I am told to by the one who sent me; and he is Truth.”

27.verse: But they still didn’t understand that he was talking to them about God.

28.verse: So Jesus said, “When you have killed the Messiah, then you will realize that I am he and that I have not been telling you my own ideas, but have spoken what the Father taught me.

29.verse: And he who sent me is with me—he has not deserted me—for I always do those things that are pleasing to him.”

30.verse: Then many of the Jewish leaders who heard him say these things began believing him to be the Messiah. Jesus said to them, “You are truly my disciples if you live as I tell you to,

31.verse: Then many of the Jewish leaders who heard him say these things began believing him to be the Messiah. Jesus said to them, “You are truly my disciples if you live as I tell you to,

32.verse: and you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.”

33.verse: “But we are descendants of Abraham,” they said, “and have never been slaves to any man on earth! What do you mean, ‘set free’?”

34.verse: Jesus replied, “You are slaves of sin, every one of you.

35.verse: And slaves don’t have rights, but the Son has every right there is!

36.verse: So if the Son sets you free, you will indeed be free—

37.verse: (Yes, I realize that you are descendants of Abraham!) And yet some of you are trying to kill me because my message does not find a home within your hearts.

38.verse: I am telling you what I saw when I was with my Father. But you are following the advice of your father.”

39.verse: “Our father is Abraham,” they declared. “No!” Jesus replied, “for if he were, you would follow his good example.

40.verse: But instead you are trying to kill me—and all because I told you the truth I heard from God. Abraham wouldn’t do a thing like that!

41.verse: No, you are obeying your real father when you act that way.” They replied, “We were not born out of wedlock—our true Father is God himself.”

42.verse: Jesus told them, “If that were so, then you would love me, for I have come to you from God. I am not here on my own, but he sent me.

43.verse: Why can’t you understand what I am saying? It is because you are prevented from doing so!

44.verse: For you are the children of your father the devil and you love to do the evil things he does. He was a murderer from the beginning and a hater of truth—there is not an iota of truth in him. When he lies, it is perfectly normal; for he is the father of liars.

45.verse: And so when I tell the truth, you just naturally don’t believe it!

46.verse: “Which of you can truthfully accuse me of one single sin? No one! And since I am telling you the truth, why don’t you believe me?

47.verse: Anyone whose Father is God listens gladly to the words of God. Since you don’t, it proves you aren’t his children.”

48.verse: “You Samaritan! Foreigner! Devil!” the Jewish leaders snarled. “Didn’t we say all along you were possessed by a demon?”

49.verse: “No,” Jesus said, “I have no demon in me. For I honor my Father—and you dishonor me.

50.verse: And though I have no wish to make myself great, God wants this for me and judges those who reject me.

51.verse: With all the earnestness I have I tell you this—no one who obeys me shall ever die!”

52.verse: The leaders of the Jews said, “Now we know you are possessed by a demon. Even Abraham and the mightiest prophets died, and yet you say that obeying you will keep a man from dying!

53.verse: So you are greater than our father Abraham, who died? And greater than the prophets, who died? Who do you think you are?”

54.verse: Then Jesus told them this: “If I am merely boasting about myself, it doesn’t count. But it is my Father—and you claim him as your God—who is saying these glorious things about me.

55.verse: But you do not even know him. I do. If I said otherwise, I would be as great a liar as you! But it is true—I know him and fully obey him.

56.verse: Your father Abraham rejoiced to see my day. He knew I was coming and was glad.”

57.verse: The Jewish leaders: “You aren’t even fifty years old—sure, you’ve seen Abraham!”

58.verse: Jesus: “The absolute truth is that I was in existence before Abraham was ever born!”

59.verse: At that point the Jewish leaders picked up stones to kill him. But Jesus was hidden from them, and walked past them and left the Temple.

1.verse: As he was walking along, he saw a man blind from birth.

2.verse: “Master,” his disciples asked him, “why was this man born blind? Was it a result of his own sins or those of his parents?”

3.verse: “Neither,” Jesus answered. “But to demonstrate the power of God.

4.verse: All of us must quickly carry out the tasks assigned us by the one who sent me, for there is little time left before the night falls and all work comes to an end.

5.verse: But while I am still here in the world, I give it my light.”

6.verse: Then he spat on the ground and made mud from the spittle and smoothed the mud over the blind man’s eyes,

7.verse: and told him, “Go and wash in the Pool of Siloam” (the word Siloam means “Sent”). So the man went where he was sent and washed and came back seeing!

8.verse: His neighbors and others who knew him as a blind beggar asked each other, “Is this the same fellow—that beggar?”

9.verse: Some said yes, and some said no. “It can’t be the same man,” they thought, “but he surely looks like him!” And the beggar said, “I am the same man!”

10.verse: Then they asked him how in the world he could see. What had happened?

11.verse: And he told them, “A man they call Jesus made mud and smoothed it over my eyes and told me to go to the Pool of Siloam and wash off the mud. I did, and I can see!”

12.verse: “Where is he now?” they asked. “I don’t know,” he replied.

13.verse: Then they took the man to the Pharisees.

14.verse: Now as it happened, this all occurred on a Sabbath.

15.verse: Then the Pharisees asked him all about it. So he told them how Jesus had smoothed the mud over his eyes, and when it was washed away, he could see!

16.verse: Some of them said, “Then this fellow Jesus is not from God because he is working on the Sabbath.” Others said, “But how could an ordinary sinner do such miracles?” So there was a deep division of opinion among them.

17.verse: Then the Pharisees turned on the man who had been blind and demanded, “This man who opened your eyes—who do you say he is?” “I think he must be a prophet sent from God,” the man replied.

18.verse: The Jewish leaders wouldn’t believe he had been blind, until they called in his parents

19.verse: and asked them, “Is this your son? Was he born blind? If so, how can he see?”

20.verse: His parents replied, “We know this is our son and that he was born blind,

21.verse: but we don’t know what happened to make him see, or who did it. He is old enough to speak for himself. Ask him.”

22.verse: They said this in fear of the Jewish leaders who had announced that anyone saying Jesus was the Messiah would be excommunicated.

23.verse: They said this in fear of the Jewish leaders who had announced that anyone saying Jesus was the Messiah would be excommunicated.

24.verse: So for the second time they called in the man who had been blind and told him, “Give the glory to God, not to Jesus, for we know Jesus is an evil person.”

25.verse: “I don’t know whether he is good or bad,” the man replied, “but I know this: I was blind, and now I see!”

26.verse: “But what did he do?” they asked. “How did he heal you?”

27.verse: “Look!” the man exclaimed. “I told you once; didn’t you listen? Why do you want to hear it again? Do you want to become his disciples too?”

28.verse: Then they cursed him and said, “You are his disciple, but we are disciples of Moses.

29.verse: We know God has spoken to Moses, but as for this fellow, we don’t know anything about him.”

30.verse: “Why, that’s very strange!” the man replied. “He can heal blind men, and yet you don’t know anything about him!

31.verse: Well, God doesn’t listen to evil men, but he has open ears to those who worship him and do his will.

32.verse: Since the world began there has never been anyone who could open the eyes of someone born blind.

33.verse: If this man were not from God, he couldn’t do it.”

34.verse: “You illegitimate bastard, you!” they shouted. “Are you trying to teach us?” And they threw him out.

35.verse: When Jesus heard what had happened, he found the man and said, “Do you believe in the Messiah?”

36.verse: The man answered, “Who is he, sir, for I want to.”

37.verse: “You have seen him,” Jesus said, “and he is speaking to you!”

38.verse: “Yes, Lord,” the man said, “I believe!” And he worshiped Jesus.

39.verse: Then Jesus told him, “I have come into the world to give sight to those who are spiritually blind and to show those who think they see that they are blind.”

40.verse: The Pharisees who were standing there asked, “Are you saying we are blind?”

41.verse: “If you were blind, you wouldn’t be guilty,” Jesus replied. “But your guilt remains because you claim to know what you are doing.

1.verse: “Anyone refusing to walk through the gate into a sheepfold, who sneaks over the wall, must surely be a thief!

2.verse: For a shepherd comes through the gate.

3.verse: The gatekeeper opens the gate for him, and the sheep hear his voice and come to him; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.

4.verse: He walks ahead of them; and they follow him, for they recognize his voice.

1.verse: Do you remember Mary, who poured the costly perfume on Jesus’ feet and wiped them with her hair? Well, her brother Lazarus, who lived in Bethany with Mary and her sister Martha, was sick.

2.verse: Do you remember Mary, who poured the costly perfume on Jesus’ feet and wiped them with her hair? Well, her brother Lazarus, who lived in Bethany with Mary and her sister Martha, was sick.

3.verse: So the two sisters sent a message to Jesus telling him, “Sir, your good friend is very, very sick.”

4.verse: But when Jesus heard about it he said, “The purpose of his illness is not death, but for the glory of God. I, the Son of God, will receive glory from this situation.”

5.verse: Although Jesus was very fond of Martha, Mary, and Lazarus,

6.verse: he stayed where he was for the next two days and made no move to go to them.

7.verse: Finally, after the two days, he said to his disciples, “Let’s go to Judea.”

8.verse: But his disciples objected. “Master,” they said, “only a few days ago the Jewish leaders in Judea were trying to kill you. Are you going there again?”

9.verse: Jesus replied, “There are twelve hours of daylight every day, and during every hour of it a man can walk safely and not stumble.

10.verse: Only at night is there danger of a wrong step, because of the dark.”

11.verse: Then he said, “Our friend Lazarus has gone to sleep, but now I will go and waken him!”

12.verse: The disciples, thinking Jesus meant Lazarus was having a good night’s rest, said, “That means he is getting better!” But Jesus meant Lazarus had died.

19.verse: and many of the Jewish leaders had come to pay their respects and to console Martha and Mary on their loss.

20.verse: When Martha got word that Jesus was coming, she went to meet him. But Mary stayed at home.

21.verse: Martha said to Jesus, “Sir, if you had been here, my brother wouldn’t have died.

22.verse: And even now it’s not too late, for I know that God will bring my brother back to life again, if you will only ask him to.”

23.verse: Jesus told her, “Your brother will come back to life again.”

24.verse: “Yes,” Martha said, “when everyone else does, on Resurrection Day.”

25.verse: Jesus told her, “I am the one who raises the dead and gives them life again. Anyone who believes in me, even though he dies like anyone else, shall live again.

26.verse: He is given eternal life for believing in me and shall never perish. Do you believe this, Martha?”

27.verse: “Yes, Master,” she told him. “I believe you are the Messiah, the Son of God, the one we have so long awaited.”

28.verse: Then she left him and returned to Mary and, calling her aside from the mourners, told her, “He is here and wants to see you.”

29.verse: So Mary went to him at once.

30.verse: Now Jesus had stayed outside the village, at the place where Martha met him.

31.verse: When the Jewish leaders who were at the house trying to console Mary saw her leave so hastily, they assumed she was going to Lazarus’ tomb to weep; so they followed her.

32.verse: When Mary arrived where Jesus was, she fell down at his feet, saying, “Sir, if you had been here, my brother would still be alive.”

33.verse: When Jesus saw her weeping and the Jewish leaders wailing with her, he was moved with indignation and deeply troubled.

34.verse: “Where is he buried?” he asked them. They told him, “Come and see.”

36.verse: “They were close friends,” the Jewish leaders said. “See how much he loved him.”

37.verse: But some said, “This fellow healed a blind man—why couldn’t he keep Lazarus from dying?” And again Jesus was moved with deep anger. Then they came to the tomb. It was a cave with a heavy stone rolled across its door.

39.verse: “Roll the stone aside,” Jesus told them. But Martha, the dead man’s sister, said, “By now the smell will be terrible, for he has been dead four days.”

40.verse: “But didn’t I tell you that you will see a wonderful miracle from God if you believe?” Jesus asked her.

41.verse: So they rolled the stone aside. Then Jesus looked up to heaven and said, “Father, thank you for hearing me.

44.verse: And Lazarus came—bound up in the gravecloth, his face muffled in a head swath. Jesus told them, “Unwrap him and let him go!”

45.verse: And so at last many of the Jewish leaders who were with Mary and saw it happen, finally believed on him.

46.verse: But some went away to the Pharisees and reported it to them.

47.verse: Then the chief priests and Pharisees convened a council to discuss the situation. “What are we going to do?” they asked each other. “For this man certainly does miracles.

48.verse: If we let him alone the whole nation will follow him—and then the Roman army will come and kill us and take over the Jewish government.”

49.verse: And one of them, Caiaphas, who was High Priest that year, said, “You stupid idiots—

50.verse: let this one man die for the people—why should the whole nation perish?”

52.verse: It was a prediction that Jesus’ death would not be for Israel only, but for all the children of God scattered around the world.

53.verse: So from that time on the Jewish leaders began plotting Jesus’ death.

54.verse: Jesus now stopped his public ministry and left Jerusalem; he went to the edge of the desert, to the village of Ephraim, and stayed there with his disciples.

55.verse: The Passover, a Jewish holy day, was near, and many country people arrived in Jerusalem several days early so that they could go through the cleansing ceremony before the Passover began.

56.verse: They wanted to see Jesus, and as they gossiped in the Temple, they asked each other, “What do you think? Will he come for the Passover?”

57.verse: Meanwhile the chief priests and Pharisees had publicly announced that anyone seeing Jesus must report him immediately so that they could arrest him.

1.verse: Six days before the Passover ceremonies began, Jesus arrived in Bethany where Lazarus was—the man he had brought back to life.

2.verse: A banquet was prepared in Jesus’ honor. Martha served, and Lazarus sat at the table with him.

3.verse: Then Mary took a jar of costly perfume made from essence of nard, and anointed Jesus’ feet with it and wiped them with her hair. And the house was filled with fragrance.

4.verse: But Judas Iscariot, one of his disciples—the one who would betray him—said,

33.verse: He said this to indicate how he was going to die.

35.verse: Jesus replied, “My light will shine out for you just a little while longer. Walk in it while you can, and go where you want to go before the darkness falls, for then it will be too late for you to find your way.

36.verse: Make use of the Light while there is still time; then you will become light bearers.” After saying these things, Jesus went away and was hidden from them.

37.verse: But despite all the miracles he had done, most of the people would not believe he was the Messiah.

39.verse: But they couldn’t believe, for as Isaiah also said:

44.verse: Jesus shouted to the crowds, “If you trust me, you are really trusting God.

46.verse: I have come as a Light to shine in this dark world, so that all who put their trust in me will no longer wander in the darkness.

47.verse: If anyone hears me and doesn’t obey me, I am not his judge—for I have come to save the world and not to judge it.

48.verse: But all who reject me and my message will be judged at the Day of Judgment by the truths I have spoken.

19.verse: The world would love you if you belonged to it; but you don’t—for I chose you to come out of the world, and so it hates you.

20.verse: Do you remember what I told you? ‘A slave isn’t greater than his master!’ So since they persecuted me, naturally they will persecute you. And if they had listened to me, they would listen to you!

21.verse: The people of the world will persecute you because you belong to me, for they don’t know God who sent me.

22.verse: “They would not be guilty if I had not come and spoken to them. But now they have no excuse for their sin.

23.verse: Anyone hating me is also hating my Father.

24.verse: If I hadn’t done such mighty miracles among them they would not be counted guilty. But as it is, they saw these miracles and yet they hated both of us—me and my Father.

25.verse: This has fulfilled what the prophets said concerning the Messiah, ‘They hated me without reason.’

26.verse: “But I will send you the Comforter—the Holy Spirit, the source of all truth. He will come to you from the Father and will tell you all about me.

27.verse: And you also must tell everyone about me because you have been with me from the beginning.

1.verse: “I have told you these things so that you won’t be staggered by all that lies ahead.

2.verse: For you will be excommunicated from the synagogues, and indeed the time is coming when those who kill you will think they are doing God a service.

3.verse: This is because they have never known the Father or me.

4.verse: Yes, I’m telling you these things now so that when they happen you will remember I warned you. I didn’t tell you earlier because I was going to be with you for a while longer.

5.verse: “But now I am going away to the one who sent me; and none of you seems interested in the purpose of my going; none wonders why.

6.verse: Instead you are only filled with sorrow.

7.verse: But the fact of the matter is that it is best for you that I go away, for if I don’t, the Comforter won’t come. If I do, he will—for I will send him to you.

8.verse: “And when he has come he will convince the world of its sin, and of the availability of God’s goodness, and of deliverance from judgment.

9.verse: The world’s sin is unbelief in me;

10.verse: there is righteousness available because I go to the Father and you shall see me no more;

11.verse: there is deliverance from judgment because the prince of this world has already been judged.

12.verse: “Oh, there is so much more I want to tell you, but you can’t understand it now.

13.verse: When the Holy Spirit, who is truth, comes, he shall guide you into all truth, for he will not be presenting his own ideas, but will be passing on to you what he has heard. He will tell you about the future.

14.verse: He shall praise me and bring me great honor by showing you my glory.

15.verse: All the Father’s glory is mine; this is what I mean when I say that he will show you my glory.

16.verse: “In just a little while I will be gone, and you will see me no more; but just a little while after that, and you will see me again!”

17.verse: “Whatever is he saying?” some of his disciples asked. “What is this about ‘going to the Father’? We don’t know what he means.”

18.verse: “Whatever is he saying?” some of his disciples asked. “What is this about ‘going to the Father’? We don’t know what he means.”

19.verse: Jesus realized they wanted to ask him so he said, “Are you asking yourselves what I mean?

20.verse: The world will greatly rejoice over what is going to happen to me, and you will weep. But your weeping shall suddenly be turned to wonderful joy when you see me again.

21.verse: It will be the same joy as that of a woman in labor when her child is born—her anguish gives place to rapturous joy and the pain is forgotten.

22.verse: You have sorrow now, but I will see you again and then you will rejoice; and no one can rob you of that joy.

23.verse: At that time you won’t need to ask me for anything, for you can go directly to the Father and ask him, and he will give you what you ask for because you use my name.

24.verse: You haven’t tried this before, but begin now. Ask, using my name, and you will receive, and your cup of joy will overflow.

25.verse: “I have spoken of these matters very guardedly, but the time will come when this will not be necessary and I will tell you plainly all about the Father.

26.verse: Then you will present your petitions over my signature! And I won’t need to ask the Father to grant you these requests,

27.verse: for the Father himself loves you dearly because you love me and believe that I came from the Father.

28.verse: Yes, I came from the Father into the world and will leave the world and return to the Father.”

29.verse: “At last you are speaking plainly,” his disciples said, “and not in riddles.

30.verse: Now we understand that you know everything and don’t need anyone to tell you anything. From this we believe that you came from God.”

31.verse: “Do you finally believe this?” Jesus asked.

32.verse: “But the time is coming—in fact, it is here—when you will be scattered, each one returning to his own home, leaving me alone. Yet I will not be alone, for the Father is with me.

33.verse: I have told you all this so that you will have peace of heart and mind. Here on earth you will have many trials and sorrows; but cheer up, for I have overcome the world.”

1.verse: When Jesus had finished saying all these things he looked up to heaven and said, “Father, the time has come. Reveal the glory of your Son so that he can give the glory back to you.

2.verse: For you have given him authority over every man and woman in all the earth. He gives eternal life to each one you have given him.

3.verse: And this is the way to have eternal life—by knowing you, the only true God, and Jesus Christ, the one you sent to earth!

4.verse: I brought glory to you here on earth by doing everything you told me to.

5.verse: And now, Father, reveal my glory as I stand in your presence, the glory we shared before the world began.

6.verse: “I have told these men all about you. They were in the world, but then you gave them to me. Actually, they were always yours, and you gave them to me; and they have obeyed you.

7.verse: Now they know that everything I have is a gift from you,

8.verse: for I have passed on to them the commands you gave me; and they accepted them and know of a certainty that I came down to earth from you, and they believe you sent me.

9.verse: “My plea is not for the world but for those you have given me because they belong to you.

10.verse: And all of them, since they are mine, belong to you; and you have given them back to me with everything else of yours, and so they are my glory!

11.verse: Now I am leaving the world, and leaving them behind, and coming to you. Holy Father, keep them in your own care—all those you have given me—so that they will be united just as we are, with none missing.

12.verse: During my time here I have kept safe within your family all of these you gave me. I guarded them so that not one perished, except the son of hell, as the Scriptures foretold.

13.verse: “And now I am coming to you. I have told them many things while I was with them so that they would be filled with my joy.

14.verse: I have given them your commands. And the world hates them because they don’t fit in with it, just as I don’t.

15.verse: I’m not asking you to take them out of the world, but to keep them safe from Satan’s power.

16.verse: They are not part of this world any more than I am.

17.verse: Make them pure and holy through teaching them your words of truth.

18.verse: As you sent me into the world, I am sending them into the world,

19.verse: and I consecrate myself to meet their need for growth in truth and holiness.

20.verse: “I am not praying for these alone but also for the future believers who will come to me because of the testimony of these.

21.verse: My prayer for all of them is that they will be of one heart and mind, just as you and I are, Father—that just as you are in me and I am in you, so they will be in us, and the world will believe you sent me.

22.verse: “I have given them the glory you gave me—the glorious unity of being one, as we are—

23.verse: I in them and you in me, all being perfected into one—so that the world will know you sent me and will understand that you love them as much as you love me.

24.verse: Father, I want them with me—these you’ve given me—so that they can see my glory. You gave me the glory because you loved me before the world began!

25.verse: “O righteous Father, the world doesn’t know you, but I do; and these disciples know you sent me.

26.verse: And I have revealed you to them and will keep on revealing you so that the mighty love you have for me may be in them, and I in them.”

1.verse: After saying these things Jesus crossed the Kidron ravine with his disciples and entered a grove of olive trees.

2.verse: Judas, the betrayer, knew this place, for Jesus had gone there many times with his disciples.

3.verse: The chief priests and Pharisees had given Judas a squad of soldiers and police to accompany him. Now with blazing torches, lanterns, and weapons they arrived at the olive grove.

4.verse: Jesus fully realized all that was going to happen to him. Stepping forward to meet them he asked, “Whom are you looking for?” “Jesus of Nazareth,” they replied. “I am he,” Jesus said.

5.verse: Jesus fully realized all that was going to happen to him. Stepping forward to meet them he asked, “Whom are you looking for?” “Jesus of Nazareth,” they replied. “I am he,” Jesus said.

6.verse: And as he said it, they all fell backwards to the ground!

7.verse: Once more he asked them, “Whom are you searching for?” And again they replied, “Jesus of Nazareth.”

8.verse: “I told you I am he,” Jesus said; “and since I am the one you are after, let these others go.”

9.verse: He did this to carry out the prophecy he had just made, “I have not lost a single one of those you gave me. . . . ”

10.verse: Then Simon Peter drew a sword and slashed off the right ear of Malchus, the High Priest’s servant.

11.verse: But Jesus said to Peter, “Put your sword away. Shall I not drink from the cup the Father has given me?”

12.verse: So the Jewish police, with the soldiers and their lieutenant, arrested Jesus and tied him.

13.verse: First they took him to Annas, the father-in-law of Caiaphas, the High Priest that year.

14.verse: Caiaphas was the one who told the other Jewish leaders, “Better that one should die for all.”

15.verse: Simon Peter followed along behind, as did another of the disciples who was acquainted with the High Priest. So that other disciple was permitted into the courtyard along with Jesus,

16.verse: while Peter stood outside the gate. Then the other disciple spoke to the girl watching at the gate, and she let Peter in.

17.verse: The girl asked Peter, “Aren’t you one of Jesus’ disciples?” “No,” he said, “I am not!”

18.verse: The police and the household servants were standing around a fire they had made, for it was cold. And Peter stood there with them, warming himself.

19.verse: Inside, the High Priest began asking Jesus about his followers and what he had been teaching them.

20.verse: Jesus replied, “What I teach is widely known, for I have preached regularly in the synagogue and Temple; I have been heard by all the Jewish leaders and teach nothing in private that I have not said in public.

21.verse: Why are you asking me this question? Ask those who heard me. You have some of them here. They know what I said.”

22.verse: One of the soldiers standing there struck Jesus with his fist. “Is that the way to answer the High Priest?” he demanded.

23.verse: “If I lied, prove it,” Jesus replied. “Should you hit a man for telling the truth?”

24.verse: Then Annas sent Jesus, bound, to Caiaphas the High Priest.

25.verse: Meanwhile, as Simon Peter was standing by the fire, he was asked again, “Aren’t you one of his disciples?” “Of course not,” he replied.

26.verse: But one of the household slaves of the High Priest—a relative of the man whose ear Peter had cut off—asked, “Didn’t I see you out there in the olive grove with Jesus?”

27.verse: Again Peter denied it. And immediately a rooster crowed.

28.verse: Jesus’ trial before Caiaphas ended in the early hours of the morning. Next he was taken to the palace of the Roman governor. His accusers wouldn’t go in themselves for that would “defile” them, they said, and they wouldn’t be allowed to eat the Passover lamb.

29.verse: So Pilate, the governor, went out to them and asked, “What is your charge against this man? What are you accusing him of doing?”

30.verse: “We wouldn’t have arrested him if he weren’t a criminal!” they retorted.

31.verse: “Then take him away and judge him yourselves by your own laws,” Pilate told them. “But we want him crucified,” they demanded, “and your approval is required.”

32.verse: This fulfilled Jesus’ prediction concerning the method of his execution.

33.verse: Then Pilate went back into the palace and called for Jesus to be brought to him. “Are you the King of the Jews?” he asked him.

34.verse: “‘King’ as you use the word or as the Jews use it?” Jesus asked.

35.verse: “Am I a Jew?” Pilate retorted. “Your own people and their chief priests brought you here. Why? What have you done?”

36.verse: Then Jesus answered, “I am not an earthly king. If I were, my followers would have fought when I was arrested by the Jewish leaders. But my Kingdom is not of the world.”

37.verse: Pilate replied, “But you are a king then?” “Yes,” Jesus said. “I was born for that purpose. And I came to bring truth to the world. All who love the truth are my followers.”

38.verse: “What is truth?” Pilate exclaimed. Then he went out again to the people and told them, “He is not guilty of any crime.

39.verse: But you have a custom of asking me to release someone from prison each year at Passover. So if you want me to, I’ll release the ‘King of the Jews.’”

40.verse: But they screamed back. “No! Not this man, but Barabbas!” Barabbas was a robber.

1.verse: Then Pilate laid open Jesus’ back with a leaded whip,

2.verse: and the soldiers made a crown of thorns and placed it on his head and robed him in royal purple.

3.verse: “Hail, ‘King of the Jews’!” they mocked, and struck him with their fists.

4.verse: Pilate went outside again and said to the Jews, “I am going to bring him out to you now, but understand clearly that I find him not guilty.”

5.verse: Then Jesus came out wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. And Pilate said, “Behold the man!”

6.verse: At sight of him the chief priests and Jewish officials began yelling, “Crucify! Crucify!” “You crucify him,” Pilate said. “I find him not guilty.”

7.verse: They replied, “By our laws he ought to die because he called himself the Son of God.”

8.verse: When Pilate heard this, he was more frightened than ever.

9.verse: He took Jesus back into the palace again and asked him, “Where are you from?” but Jesus gave no answer.

10.verse: “You won’t talk to me?” Pilate demanded. “Don’t you realize that I have the power to release you or to crucify you?”

11.verse: Then Jesus said, “You would have no power at all over me unless it were given to you from above. So those who brought me to you have the greater sin.”

12.verse: Then Pilate tried to release him, but the Jewish leaders told him, “If you release this man, you are no friend of Caesar’s. Anyone who declares himself a king is a rebel against Caesar.”

13.verse: At these words Pilate brought Jesus out to them again and sat down at the judgment bench on the stone-paved platform.

14.verse: It was now about noon of the day before Passover. And Pilate said to the Jews, “Here is your king!”

15.verse: “Away with him,” they yelled. “Away with him—crucify him!” “What? Crucify your king?” Pilate asked. “We have no king but Caesar,” the chief priests shouted back.

16.verse: Then Pilate gave Jesus to them to be crucified.

17.verse: So they had him at last, and he was taken out of the city, carrying his cross to the place known as “The Skull,” in Hebrew, “Golgotha.”

18.verse: There they crucified him and two others with him, one on either side, with Jesus between them.

19.verse: And Pilate posted a sign over him reading, “Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews.”

20.verse: The place where Jesus was crucified was near the city; and the signboard was written in Hebrew, Latin, and Greek, so that many people read it.

21.verse: Then the chief priests said to Pilate, “Change it from ‘The King of the Jews’ to ‘He said, I am King of the Jews.’”

22.verse: Pilate replied, “What I have written, I have written. It stays exactly as it is.”

23.verse: When the soldiers had crucified Jesus, they put his garments into four piles, one for each of them. But they said, “Let’s not tear up his robe,” for it was seamless. “Let’s throw dice to see who gets it.” This fulfilled the Scripture that says, “They divided my clothes among them and cast lots for my robe.”

24.verse: When the soldiers had crucified Jesus, they put his garments into four piles, one for each of them. But they said, “Let’s not tear up his robe,” for it was seamless. “Let’s throw dice to see who gets it.” This fulfilled the Scripture that says, “They divided my clothes among them and cast lots for my robe.”

25.verse: So that is what they did. Standing near the cross were Jesus’ mother, Mary, his aunt, the wife of Cleopas, and Mary Magdalene.

26.verse: When Jesus saw his mother standing there beside me, his close friend, he said to her, “He is your son.”

27.verse: And to me he said, “She is your mother!” And from then on I took her into my home.

28.verse: Jesus knew that everything was now finished, and to fulfill the Scriptures said, “I’m thirsty.”

29.verse: A jar of sour wine was sitting there, so a sponge was soaked in it and put on a hyssop branch and held up to his lips.

30.verse: When Jesus had tasted it, he said, “It is finished,” and bowed his head and dismissed his spirit.

31.verse: The Jewish leaders didn’t want the victims hanging there the next day, which was the Sabbath (and a very special Sabbath at that, for it was the Passover), so they asked Pilate to order the legs of the men broken to hasten death; then their bodies could be taken down.

32.verse: So the soldiers came and broke the legs of the two men crucified with Jesus;

33.verse: but when they came to him, they saw that he was dead already, so they didn’t break his.

34.verse: However, one of the soldiers pierced his side with a spear, and blood and water flowed out.

35.verse: I saw all this myself and have given an accurate report so that you also can believe.

36.verse: The soldiers did this in fulfillment of the Scripture that says, “Not one of his bones shall be broken,” and, “They shall look on him whom they pierced.”

37.verse: The soldiers did this in fulfillment of the Scripture that says, “Not one of his bones shall be broken,” and, “They shall look on him whom they pierced.”

38.verse: Afterwards Joseph of Arimathea, who had been a secret disciple of Jesus for fear of the Jewish leaders, boldly asked Pilate for permission to take Jesus’ body down; and Pilate told him to go ahead. So he came and took it away.

39.verse: Nicodemus, the man who had come to Jesus at night, came too, bringing a hundred pounds of embalming ointment made from myrrh and aloes.

40.verse: Together they wrapped Jesus’ body in a long linen cloth saturated with the spices, as is the Jewish custom of burial.

41.verse: The place of crucifixion was near a grove of trees, where there was a new tomb, never used before.

42.verse: And so, because of the need for haste before the Sabbath, and because the tomb was close at hand, they laid him there.

1.verse: Early Sunday morning, while it was still dark, Mary Magdalene came to the tomb and found that the stone was rolled aside from the entrance.

2.verse: She ran and found Simon Peter and me and said, “They have taken the Lord’s body out of the tomb, and I don’t know where they have put him!”

3.verse: We ran to the tomb to see; I* outran Peter and got there first,

4.verse: We ran to the tomb to see; I* outran Peter and got there first,

5.verse: and stooped and looked in and saw the linen cloth lying there, but I didn’t go in.

6.verse: Then Simon Peter arrived and went on inside. He also noticed the cloth lying there,

7.verse: while the swath that had covered Jesus’ head was rolled up in a bundle and was lying at the side.

8.verse: Then I went in too, and saw, and believed that he had risen—

9.verse: for until then we hadn’t realized that the Scriptures said he would come to life again!

10.verse: We went on home,

11.verse: and by that time Mary had returned to the tomb and was standing outside crying. And as she wept, she stooped and looked in

12.verse: and saw two white-robed angels sitting at the head and foot of the place where the body of Jesus had been lying.

13.verse: “Why are you crying?” the angels asked her. “Because they have taken away my Lord,” she replied, “and I don’t know where they have put him.”

14.verse: She glanced over her shoulder and saw someone standing behind her. It was Jesus, but she didn’t recognize him!

15.verse: “Why are you crying?” he asked her. “Whom are you looking for?” She thought he was the gardener. “Sir,” she said, “if you have taken him away, tell me where you have put him, and I will go and get him.”

16.verse: “Mary!” Jesus said. She turned toward him. “Master!” she exclaimed.

17.verse: “Don’t touch me,” he cautioned, “for I haven’t yet ascended to the Father. But go find my brothers and tell them that I ascend to my Father and your Father, my God and your God.”

18.verse: Mary Magdalene found the disciples and told them, “I have seen the Lord!” Then she gave them his message.

19.verse: That evening the disciples were meeting behind locked doors, in fear of the Jewish leaders, when suddenly Jesus was standing there among them! After greeting them,

20.verse: he showed them his hands and side. And how wonderful was their joy as they saw their Lord!

21.verse: He spoke to them again and said, “As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.”

22.verse: Then he breathed on them and told them, “Receive the Holy Spirit.

23.verse: If you forgive anyone’s sins, they are forgiven. If you refuse to forgive them, they are unforgiven.”

24.verse: One of the disciples, Thomas, “The Twin,” was not there at the time with the others.

25.verse: When they kept telling him, “We have seen the Lord,” he replied, “I won’t believe it unless I see the nail wounds in his hands—and put my fingers into them—and place my hand into his side.”

26.verse: Eight days later the disciples were together again, and this time Thomas was with them. The doors were locked; but suddenly, as before, Jesus was standing among them and greeting them.

27.verse: Then he said to Thomas, “Put your finger into my hands. Put your hand into my side. Don’t be faithless any longer. Believe!”

28.verse: “My Lord and my God!” Thomas said.

29.verse: Then Jesus told him, “You believe because you have seen me. But blessed are those who haven’t seen me and believe anyway.”

30.verse: Jesus’ disciples saw him do many other miracles besides the ones told about in this book, but these are recorded so that you will believe that he is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that believing in him you will have life.

31.verse: Jesus’ disciples saw him do many other miracles besides the ones told about in this book, but these are recorded so that you will believe that he is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that believing in him you will have life.

1.verse: Later Jesus appeared again to the disciples beside the Lake of Galilee. This is how it happened:

2.verse: A group of us were there—Simon Peter, Thomas, “The Twin,” Nathanael from Cana in Galilee, my brother James and I and two other disciples.

3.verse: Simon Peter said, “I’m going fishing.” “We’ll come too,” we all said. We did, but caught nothing all night.

4.verse: At dawn we saw a man standing on the beach but couldn’t see who he was.

5.verse: He called, “Any fish, boys?” “No,” we replied.

6.verse: Then he said, “Throw out your net on the right-hand side of the boat, and you’ll get plenty of them!” So we did, and couldn’t draw in the net because of the weight of the fish, there were so many!

7.verse: Then I said to Peter, “It is the Lord!” At that, Simon Peter put on his tunic (for he was stripped to the waist) and jumped into the water and swam ashore.*

8.verse: The rest of us stayed in the boat and pulled the loaded net to the beach, about 300 feet away.

9.verse: When we got there, we saw that a fire was kindled and fish were frying over it, and there was bread.

10.verse: “Bring some of the fish you’ve just caught,” Jesus said.

11.verse: So Simon Peter went out and dragged the net ashore. By his count there were 153 large fish; and yet the net hadn’t torn.

12.verse: “Now come and have some breakfast!” Jesus said; and none of us dared ask him if he really was the Lord, for we were quite sure of it.

13.verse: Then Jesus went around serving us the bread and fish.

14.verse: This was the third time Jesus had appeared to us since his return from the dead.

15.verse: After breakfast Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of John, do you love me more than these others?” “Yes,” Peter replied, “you know I am your friend.” “Then feed my lambs,” Jesus told him.

16.verse: Jesus repeated the question: “Simon, son of John, do you really love me?” “Yes, Lord,” Peter said, “you know I am your friend.” “Then take care of my sheep,” Jesus said.

17.verse: Once more he asked him, “Simon, son of John, are you even my friend?” Peter was grieved at the way Jesus asked the question this third time. “Lord, you know my heart; you know I am,” he said. Jesus said, “Then feed my little sheep.

18.verse: When you were young, you were able to do as you liked and go wherever you wanted to; but when you are old, you will stretch out your hands and others will direct you and take you where you don’t want to go.”

19.verse: Jesus said this to let him know what kind of death he would die to glorify God. Then Jesus told him, “Follow me.”

20.verse: Peter turned around and saw the disciple Jesus loved following, the one who had leaned around at supper that time to ask Jesus, “Master, which of us will betray you?”

21.verse: Peter asked Jesus, “What about him, Lord? What sort of death will he die?”

22.verse: Jesus replied, “If I want him to live until I return, what is that to you? You follow me.”

23.verse: So the rumor spread among the brotherhood that that disciple wouldn’t die! But that isn’t what Jesus said at all! He only said, “If I want him to live* until I come, what is that to you?”

24.verse: I am that disciple! I saw these events and have recorded them here. And we all know that my account of these things is accurate.

25.verse: And I suppose that if all the other events in Jesus’ life were written, the whole world could hardly contain the books!
